Turner-Hall: What does the surname Turner-Hall mean?

The last name Turner-Hall is a compound surname, likely of British origin, combining two different family names. The name "Turner" primarily derives from an occupational title, referring to someone who works with a lathe, turning wood, metal, or other materials. In medieval times, this was a vital craft in producing a variety of goods, so the surname is quite common in English-speaking countries, and it spread globally.

The name "Hall," on the other hand, often refers to someone who either worked in or lived by a large manor house or hall. In some cases, it might mean the person was the lord or steward of the hall. The second part of the surname usually comes from the mother's family name, especially in situations where it was important to maintain that lineage's name.

So, Turner-Hall could potentially indicate a family history involving skilled craftsman who had a close association with a significant manor or hall. However, as with many compound surnames, the actual specific meaning can vary widely based on individual family history.

Turner-Hall: Where does the name Turner-Hall come from?

The last name Turner-Hall is believed to have originated in England, and is one of many variations of the surname Turner. Today the surname is most common in the United States. According to U.S. Census Bureau records from 2010, the surname had the highest concentration of families in the southeastern states of Georgia and Alabama, though small populations were found to be living in other regions across the country.

Within those two states, a large concentration of Turner-Hall families has been found in or around larger cities such as Atlanta, Birmingham, Mobile, Montgomery, and Columbus. It has also been reported that a smaller population exists in the nearby small towns and rural areas of these two states.

The number of people with the last name Turner-Hall has shown an increase over the last few years in the United States, though the proportions are still relatively small. It has been suggested that the trend is the result of a combination of intermarriage and increased mobility. The turner-hall last name has also been documented in other countries, such as Canada and the United Kingdom.

Variations of the surname Turner-Hall

The Turner-Hall surname has several variants, spellings and surnames of the same origin. Some of these variations include Turnhall, Thurnhall, Turnall, Tournhall, and Thurnall.

Turner-Hall is a patronymic name sometimes spelled Terner-Hall, meaning “son of Turner” or “son of the Turner”. The base string is “turn” or “turnen”, meaning “to turn”. This would indicate that the original bearer of this surname likely worked with hand tools such as a lathe or spindle.

Turner-Hall is also an Anglo-Saxon surname derived from the Old English personal names Tura and Hald, meaning “thorn” and “to hold” respectively. This could indicate that the original bearer of this surname likely held a position of power, authority or direction within their community.

The spelling and surname variations of Turner-Hall can also be found in other forms such as Turnar-Hall, Thornar-Hall, Turmer-Hall, Torner-Hall, Tornerall and Turmerall.

Turner-Hall is a fairly common surname in Great Britain. Variations of this surname, such as Thurnall and Turnhall, can also be found in North America, particularly in the United States.
